column6: description
The angle between the larva's tail vector, and a vector from the middle of the larva to its head. The absolute bending angle indicates how much the larva is bent, independent from direction.
column7: 180° that it are oriented directly away from the odour.

column6: The angle between the larva's tail vector, and a vector from the middle of the larva to its head. Positive values indicate the larva bending to the left, negative values bending to the right.
column7: 180° that it are oriented directly away from the odour. Positive values indicate the odour is to the right  negative values that the odour is to the left.

column6: The distance of an animal to its starting point.
The angular speed of the head vector (HV). Positive values indicate movement of the head to the right, negative values to the left.
column7: and a vector from the middle of the larva to its head. The absolute bending angle indicates how much the larva is bent  independent from direction.

column6: The velocity of the larva's head point in forward direction, that is, in direction of the head vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.
column7: negative values to the left.

column6: The speed of the larva's head point (measured in body lengths per second) in forward direction, that is, in direction of the head vector.
The accumulated distance a larva has traveled up to given time point
column7: independent of direction.

column6: The distance the larva has travelled so far, measured in body lengths.
column7: independent of direction.

column6: The speed of the larva's midpoint, independent of direction.
column7: that is  in direction of the tail vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.

column6: The speed of the larva's midpoint (measured in body lengths per second), independent of direction.
column7: that is  in direction of the tail vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.

column6: The angular speed of the tail vector (TV). Positive values indicate movement to the right, negative values to the left.
column7: negative values to the left.

column6: The velocity of the larva's tail point in forward direction, that is, in direction of the tail vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.
column7: that is  in direction of the head vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.

column6: The speed of the larva's tail point (measured in body lengths per second) in forward direction, that is, in direction of the tail vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.
column7: that is  in direction of the head vector. Any lateral speed component is ignored.

column6: The HC angle is calculated as the bending angle after minus before a HC. The absolute HC angle is an estimate for the size of the HC, independent from direction.
column7: negative values that it was to the right.

column6: The HC angle is calculated as the bending angle after minus before a HC. Positive values indicate that the HC was to the left, negative values that it was to the right.

The absolute heading angle before a HC minus the absolute heading angle after the HC. Positive values indicate that the larva is oriented more towards the odour after the HC, negative values that the larva is oriented more away.
column7: independent from direction.

column6: The inter-step (IS) angle indicates how much the orientation of the animal changes within one cycle of peristaltic forward movement. It is defined as the angle between a larva's head vector at one step minus the head vector at the previous step. A step is defined as the local maximum of the tail forward velocity during runs.
column7: negative values that it changes its orientation to the right.

column6: The inter-step (IS) angle indicates how much the orientation of the animal changes within one cycle of peristaltic forward movement. It is defined as the angle between a larva's head vector at one step minus the head vector at the previous step. A step is defined as the local maximum of the tail forward velocity during runs. Positive values indicate that the larva changes its orientation to the left, negative values that it changes its orientation to the right.
column7: negative values that the larva is oriented more away.

column6: The inter-step (IS) distance measures the distance of the larva's #MT midpoint between two steps. A step is defined as the local maximum of the tail forward velocity during runs.
The inter-step (IS) distance measures the distance of the larva's #MT midpoint between two steps in body lengths. A step is defined as the local maximum of the Tail velocity during runs.
column7: measured in body lengths.

column6: The inter-step (IS) interval measures the time between two steps. A step is defined as the local maximum of the tail forward velocity during runs.
column7: negative values that it changes its orientation away from the odour.

column6: The midpoint speed during runs
The number of extrem points in step

The bearing angle is the angle between the tail vector and the vector from the animal towards the odour. 0° indicates that larvae are oriented directly towards the odour, 180° that they are oriented directly away from the odour.
column7: and a vector from the middle of the larva to its head. Positive values indicate the larva bending to the left negative values bending to the right.

column6: The heading angle is the angle between the head vector and the vector from the animal towards the odour. 0° indicates that the larva's head is oriented directly towards the odour, 180° that it are oriented directly away from the odour.
column7: 180° that they are oriented directly away from the odour.

column6: The bearing angle is the angle between the tail vector and the vector from the animal towards the odour. 0° indicates that larvae are oriented directly towards the odour, 180° that they are oriented directly away from the odour. Positive values indicate the odour is to the right, negative values that the odour is to the left.
The distance of an animal from the odour source.
column7: negative values that the animal is moving away.

column6: The heading angle is the angle between the head vector and the vector from the animal towards the odour. 0° indicates that the larva's head is oriented directly towards the odour, 180° that it are oriented directly away from the odour. Positive values indicate the odour is to the right, negative values that the odour is to the left.
column7: 180° that they are oriented directly away from the odour. Positive values indicate the odour is to the right negative values that the odour is to the left.

column6: The inter-step (IS) reorientation indicates how much the orientation of the animal with respect to the odour changes within one cycle of peristaltic forward movement. It is calculated as the larva's heading angle at one step minus the heading angle at the previous step. A step is defined as the local maximum of the tail forward velocity during runs. Positive values indicate that the larva changes its orientation towards the odour, negative values that it changes its orientation away from the odour.
The velocity of the larva's midpoint in direction of the odour. Positive values indicate that the animal is moving toward the odour, negative values that the animal is moving away.
